title: How to Clean a Loofah or Natural Sponge

steps.title: Rinse it well.
steps.content: Rinse it well. Rinse your loofah well after each use and squeeze and shake out excess water. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Keep it dry.
steps.content: Keep it dry. Bacteria loves growing in wet places, so keep your loofah dry to prevent it from becoming a breeding ground for nasty germs that cause folliculitis, yeast, and fungal infections. [2] X Research source Once you've rinsed your loofah, store it in a cool, dry place.

steps.title: Disinfect it.
steps.content: Disinfect it. Loofahs start out hygienic, but the accumulation of dead skin cells and storage in humid environments turns it into a bacteria haven. Soak your loofah in diluted bleach for five minutes each week to kill bacteria and germs. [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Use essential natural oils.
steps.content: Use essential natural oils. Essential oils have antimicrobial properties that help deter bacterial growth. They also contain no irritants or harsh chemicals, which is good for both your skin and the environment. [4] X Research source On a weekly basis, soak your loofah in a solution made up of warm water and a few drops of pure essential oils. You can purchase essential oils from most health food stores.

steps.title: Microwave it to kill the germs.
steps.content: Microwave it to kill the germs. Your microwave is a powerful weapon in killing germs and infection causing bacteria. You can periodically microwave a synthetic loofah for two minutes to decontaminate it. Before placing the loofah in microwave, make sure it is completely wet and does not contain any metal parts to avoid the risk of fire. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wash your loofah in the washing machine.
steps.content: Wash your loofah in the washing machine. Go ahead and give your loofah a spin in your washing machine! You should wash it every week in cold water using a mild or gentle cycle. Do not put the sponge in the dryer as the natural fibers will melt. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Know when it’s time to throw it away.
steps.content: Know when it’s time to throw it away. Avoid becoming so attached to your loofah that you keep it around when it’s no longer safe to use. Discard your loofah if you notice mold growth or if it smells mildewy or musty. Doing so will help prevent you from catching a nasty skin infection. Replace a natural loofah every three to four weeks. Synthetic loofahs can be used for up to two months. [7] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Decide on whether to purchase a natural or synthetic loofah.
steps.content: Decide on whether to purchase a natural or synthetic loofah. There are many different natural and synthetic loofah products on the market. Be aware that loofahs made from natural substances do not last as long as those used in synthetic sponges. Synthetic sponges will last longer on average and require less maintenance.

steps.title: Consider an alternative to a loofah.
steps.content: Consider an alternative to a loofah. Loofahs are a favorite bath and shower accessory for many people; however, because of all the nooks and crannies in a loofah, it is very susceptible in breeding bacteria. You might want to consider ditching the use of loofahs for a more sanitary alternative instead. Washcloths tend to be used more frequently and easier to wash and dry. In addition they accumulate less bacteria due to their physical structure. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you can't bare to part with your loofah, then alternate days between using a washcloth and a loofah.
